Localisation.report_string:
--- Localisation ---
Agree with lesion involving:
- left optic nerve (cranial nerve II).

Differential diagnosis.report_string:
--- Differential diagnosis ---
Correctly included: Multiple sclerosis
  
These suggested differentials are reasonable:

- MOG antibody–associated optic neuritis; Aquaporin-4 NMOSD optic neuritis; Compressive optic neuropathy of the left optic nerve; Non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy; Sarcoid optic neuropathy; Syphilitic optic neuritis; Leber hereditary optic neuropathy; Toxic-nutritional optic neuropathy

ft_diagnoses_raw: Compressive optic neuropathy of the left optic nerve
additional_diagnoses: Compressive optic neuropathy of the left optic nerve

Investigations.report_string:
--- Investigations ---
Agree with all suggestions.

- MRI including the Orbits and CSF test for Oligoclonal Bands would potentially inform a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

ft_proposed_investigations: MRI orbits and brain with gadolinium and fat-suppressed sequences
Optical coherence tomography (retinal nerve fibre layer and macula)
Comprehensive ophthalmological examination with dilated fundoscopy
MRI of cervical and thoracic spine with gadolinium
Lumbar puncture with CSF cell count, protein, glucose, oligoclonal bands and IgG index

Management.report_string:
--- Management ---
Steroids: Unsafe decision to start treatment now.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Presenting complaint not specified, so no indication whether this is a new or an old deficit.

- Need to know comorbidities to ensure no contraindications to immunosuppression.

DMTs: Appropriate decision to consider but delay treatment.
  
Correctly identified the following:

- Need confirmation of MS diagnosis.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Need to know comorbidities to ensure no contraindications to immunosuppression.

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days
reasons: Typical unilateral optic neuritis pattern with left RAPD and reduced acuity
Early high-dose steroids hasten visual recovery
No systemic red flags for infection or sepsis
MRI will be arranged urgently to exclude compression; benefits outweigh risks
Concomitant high-dose corticosteroid therapy
Reduces risk of steroid-induced gastritis/ulcer

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Oral prednisolone taper after IV pulse
reasons: Initiate only after IV methylprednisolone course
Avoid oral steroid monotherapy which increases relapse risk in demyelinating optic neuritis
Reserve for severe vision loss or failure to improve within 3–7 days of IV steroids
Particularly effective in NMOSD/MOGAD
Start only if MRI/CSF confirm MS
Choice depends on risk profile and patient preference

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Targeted therapy for NMOSD (e.g., rituximab or satralizumab)
reasons: Initiate only if AQP4-IgG positive or diagnostic criteria met
Prevents relapses causing permanent vision loss

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Pathogen-directed antimicrobial therapy if infectious optic neuritis confirmed
reasons: Avoid steroids alone in untreated infection
Tailor to organism such as IV penicillin for syphilis or anti-tuberculous therapy for TB

ft_plan.treatment: Intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days
reasons: Typical unilateral optic neuritis pattern with left RAPD and reduced acuity
Early high-dose steroids hasten visual recovery
No systemic red flags for infection or sepsis
MRI will be arranged urgently to exclude compression; benefits outweigh risks

missing_information: Presenting complaint not specified, so no indication whether this is a new or an old deficit.
A safety screen for patient-specific comorbidities is required to identify contraindications to immunosuppressive therapy.
